chunks.text: And these are components of the blood and the urine  mainly, but also of the stool, saliva, spinal fluid,  fluid taken off the belly, joint fluid, bone marrow,  stuff coming out of your lungs.  It's anything, right?

chunks.text: of any body tissue, for example, biopsy samples  or surgical scraps.  If they do an operation, they cut something out of you.  That typically winds up on a pathologist's bench, who  then tries to figure out what its characteristics are.

chunks.text: And that's, again, useful information.  OK, microbiology.  Ever since Pasteur, we know that organisms cause disease.  And so we are quite interested in knowing what organisms  are growing inside your body.

chunks.text: designed by accountants.  And they were designed for the purpose of billing.  And so we capture a lot of data about formalized ways  of describing the condition of the patient  and what was done to the patient in order

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: to submit the right bills.  You obviously want to bill for as much as possible.  But you have to be able to justify the bills  that you submit because insurance companies and Medicare  and Medicaid don't have a good sense of humor.

chunks.text: And if you submit bills for things that you can't justify,  then you get penalized.  And then there are administrative data  like which service are you on.  So this is occasionally a confusing thing.

chunks.text: to another in the hospital.  Imaging data.  So I'm not going to talk about that much today.  But there are x-rays, ultrasound, CT, MRI, PET scans,  retinal scans, endoscopy, photographs of your skin,

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: and stuff like that.  So this is all imaging data.  And there's been a tremendous amount of progress  recently in applying machine learning techniques  to try to interpret the contents of these data.

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: So these are also very important.  And then there's the whole quantified self movement.  How many of you wear an activity tracker?  Only about a third?  I'm surprised at a place like MIT.

chunks.text: So we measure steps and elevation change and workouts.  And you can record vital signs and diet and your blood sugar,  especially if you're diabetic, allergies, allergic incidents.  There's all this mindfulness, mood, sleep, pain,  sexual activity.

chunks.text: And then people have developed this idea  of N of 1 experiments, where, for example, I  had a student some years ago who suffered from psoriasis.  It's a proteic condition of the skin.  And the problem is there are no good cures for it.

chunks.text: And so people who suffer from psoriasis  try all kinds of things.  They stop eating nuts for a while,  or they douse themselves with vinegar,  or they do whatever crazy thing comes to mind.

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: act like a scientist.  Have hypotheses.  Take good notes.  Collect good data.  Be cognizant of things like onset periods,

chunks.title: part.001.mp3

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: be confused about whether this is  the effect of the thing you were on before or the new thing  that you're trying.  So there's all sorts of ideas like that.  OK, so this is a slide from our paper on MIMIC3.
